metadata.title: From App Idea to App Store
metadata.author: Tree Document Format
metadata.description: Pathways from having an app idea to getting it live in the app store, including common dead ends.

nodes.content: You have an idea for a mobile app. You believe it solves a real problem and could attract users.
You research the market, talk to potential users, and assess whether the idea has legs.
You skip validation and jump straight into building. You're excited and confident.
You build a minimal prototype to test core functionality and get early feedback.
Research shows the market is saturated or the problem isn't painful enough. You shelve the idea.
You develop a minimum viable product with just enough features to test with real users.
You spend 8 months building every feature you can imagine. No users have seen it yet.
You release a beta to a small group of users. You're gathering feedback and fixing bugs.
Beta feedback is devastating. Users don't care about your solution. You quit.
The app is stable, polished, and tested. You prepare your app store listing, screenshots, and metadata.
You submit the app for review by the app store.
The app store rejects your submission for guideline violations.
You fix the guideline violations and resubmit.
Repeated rejections drain your motivation. The app never launches.
Your app is live in the app store. Users can find, download, and use it.
You run out of funding before the app is ready. Development stops.

edges.label: Build without direction, run out of money
